From the political point of view I see no objection to the proposed reduction, but it seems probable that, in spite of other means of transmitting money to India, the Post Office will find that the reduced charge for money orders will result in their having considerable accumulations of cash just at the time when it cannot be remitted to India except on payment of the charge for drafts. 5. The Postal Authorities from time to time ask me to absorb their cash balances, and, though I finance the Agency largely from thao source, I cannot take up all their accumulations of cash. I am not, therefore, clear as to the object of introducing a change, which will be likely to result in still greater accumulation of cash. 6. titleInfo.title: 'File 14/6 Postal commission on Government Servants' money orders'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers in the file are arranged chronologically. There are notes at the end of the file, on folios 42-44. The notes are arranged chronologically and refer to documents within the file; they give a brief description of the correspondence with a reference number, which refers back to that correspondence in the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the inside back cover with 46; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional mixed foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 4-17; these numbers are written in pencil, but are not circled.

mods.abstract: A 1930s file which includes material from 1909-1911 collected for reference (folios 2-25). There are no papers between 1911 and 1933. The file concerns the establishment of money order service between Bahrain and Turkey and between Bahrain and India, and its increase from 1933.The correspondents are: the Foreign Office; the Post-Master General at Bombay; the Director of Posts and Telegraphs, Sind and Baluchistan Circle, at Karachi; the Sub-Postmaster at Bahrain; the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf at Bushire; and the Political Agent at Bahrain.
